conclusion: Total internal reflection occurs when a light wave traveling in a denser medium hits the boundary with a less dense medium at an angle greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle θ_c is given by θ_c = sin^(-1)(1/n) where n is the refractive index of the glass for the particular light.

premise: Light with a higher refractive index will have a smaller critical angle, meaning it will undergo total internal reflection at a smaller angle of incidence.
conclusion: Light b has a higher refractive index in the glass compared to light a.
In the diagram, the angle of refraction r is smaller for light b compared to light a.

premise: Light b has a higher refractive index.
conclusion: The critical angle θ_{c,b} for light b will be smaller than that for light a, θ_{c,a}.

premise: As the angle of incidence is gradually increased, light b will reach its critical angle first because it has the smaller critical angle.
conclusion: Light b will undergo total internal reflection first.
